data.title: London United Busways

It is a subsidiary of the RATP Group and operates services under contract to Transport for London. Template:TOClimit London United was...
data.text:
Template:Use dmy dates

For London United Tramways (1894 - 1933), see London United Tramways.

London United

London United is a bus company operating in Greater London. It is a subsidiary of the RATP Group and operates services under contract to Transport for London.

Template:TOClimit

Company history[]

London United was established in December 1988[1] as one of 12 operating subsidiaries of London Buses in preparation for privatisation. In November 1994 it was sold in a management buyout.

The company's name was derived from the former London United Tramways, that operated trams and trolleybuses in west and south west London until absorbed by the London Passenger Transport Board in 1933. London United adopted the former tram company's ensignia, based on the coat of arms of the City of London, as its logo.

In 1995, London United purchased the Westlink business from Stanwell Buses Limited[2] with garages in Hounslow Heath and Kingston upon Thames.

In August 1997 London United was sold to Transdev. In 2002 Transdev purchased fellow London operator London Sovereign from the Blazefield Group.[3]

In April 2006 both operations were rebranded with the Transdev name and logo, removing the London United and London Sovereign brands, although both companies continued as separate legal entities.

In November 2009 Transdev purchased NCP Challenger with seven Transport for London contracted routes, 87 buses and garages at Park Royal and Twickenham.[4] These were integrated into the London United business.

Mergers and demergers[]

In 2009 Transdev's majority owner, Caisse des dépôts et consignations, commenced negotiating with Veolia Environnement to merge Transdev with Veolia Transport. As part of the resulting agreement, it was agreed that the RATP Group, which had a minority shareholding in Transdev, would take over ownership of some of Transdev's operations in lieu of cash payment.

This resulted in London United transferring to the RATP Group, while London Sovereign remained with Transdev and become part of the merged Veolia Transdev group.[5][6][7][8]

This agreement took effect in March 2011, and RATP Group renamed its newly acquired business London United.[9]

Livery[]

London United had an all red livery with a light grey skirt. This was later changed to all red to comply with Transport for London requirements.

But sometimes

Garages[]

London United operates eight bus garages.

Fulwell (FW)[]

Main article: Fulwell Bus Garage

As of 2023, Fulwell garage operates London bus routes 33, 65, 71, 216, 371, 481, K3, 24-hour routes 85 and 281, school routes 681 and night routes N33 and N65.

Fulwell also operate shuttle buses to and from Twickenham Stadium on behalf of the Rugby Football Union on match days.

History[]

When new, the Template:Convert/acre site was described as one of the finest plants in the country and was the main depot of London United Tramways with 20 covered tracks. The garage is nowadays divided into two sections, one used by London United, with an entrance off Wellington Road, and the other by Abellio London with an entrance off Stanley Road.

Fulwell was the first garage in London to receive trolleybuses in 1931, and together with Isleworth was the last to operate them until 1962. The last trams operated from the depot in 1935, although some of the tram tracks were, until recently, still visible in the cobbled surface of the Stanley Road entrance. The garage has never reached its capacity, even taking in much of the work from Twickenham when it closed in 1970, and in 2001 107 buses were allocated. In 1999 the garage housed 13 London Country buses after Arriva Croydon & North Surrey shut its Leatherhead garage. The buses on route 85 were operated from the forecourt with Arriva drivers. The large forecourt is at present partly used as the bus stand for route route 267.

On 5 September 2011, route 110 was transferred to this garage from Hounslow (AV) garage.

On 1 October 2011, route 290 passed to Abellio London.

On 2 March 2013, route 33 was transferred to this garage from Twickenham (NC) garage.

On 31 May 2014, route 391 was transferred to this garage from Stamford Brook (V) garage.

On 4 October 2014, route 110 was transferred to Hounslow (AV) garage from this garage.

On 8 August 2015, route 216 was transferred to Hounslow Heath (HH) garage from this garage.

On 2 July 2016, route 216 was transferred to this garage from Hounslow Heath (HH) garage, except certain trips worked off route 696 allocation. Routes 71 (except certain trips worked off route 65 night allocation) and 671 were transferred to Tolworth (TV) garage at the same time.

On 7 August 2017, part of route 131's allocation was transferred to this garage.

On 29 August 2017, the Fulwell (FW) allocation for route 131 was transferred from this garage to Tolworth (TV) garge.

On 30 June 2018, London United RATP recommenced operating route K3 and route 419 was transferred to this garage from Hounslow (AV) garage.

On 29 September 2018, London United commenced operating route N65.

On 24 November 2018, Route 391 was transferred from this garage to Stamford Brook (V) garage and route 411 was transferred from Quality Line's Epsom (EB) garage to this garage.

On 18 May 2019, London United commenced operating route N33.

On 9 November 2019, Route 267 passed to Abellio London.

On 27 June 2020 the allocation of routes 71 and 671 were transferred to this garage from Tolworth (TV) garage.

On 8 May 2021, London United commenced operation on route 481. At the same time routes 216 and 411 were transferred to Hounslow Heath (HH) garage from this garage.

On 12 June 2021 the allocation of routes 85, 406 school extra only and 418 school extra only was transferred to this garage. At the same time route 419 was transferred to Hounslow (AV) garage.

On 21 June 2021, routes 406 (school extras) and 418 (school extras) have been withdrawn.

On 1 July 2023, route 216 was transferred to this garage.

Bus types in use []

Alexander Dennis Enviro 200 Dart 10.2m (DE) for routes 33, K3 and N33

Volvo B5LH 10.5m / Wright Eclipse Gemini 2 (VH) for routes 85, to be introduced to route 216 from TBC

Volvo B5LH 10.6m / Wright Eclipse Gemini 3 (VH) for routes 85, 481 and 681

BYD DD 10.9m / Enviro 400 City EV (BCE) for routes 65, 281, 371, and N65

Scania OmniCity 10.8m (SP) for routes 71 and 681

Hounslow (AV)[]

As of May 2022, Hounslow garage operates London bus routes 110, 117, 203, 419, H22, H98 and Weekend night routes E1, H32 and H37

History[]

Hounslow garage was opened by the London General Omnibus Company in 1913 on the former site of the District Railway's Hounslow Town station. The garage along with many others was requisitioned in the First World War. Hounslow was the subject of two firsts in 1925 and 1930 with the first pneumatic tyre buses and the original Dennis Dart allocated respectively. The garage had one problem though: the roof was too low and only open toppers and single deck vehicles could use the depot until the mid-1930s when the roof was raised.

A London Transport survey in 1947 found that 92 vehicles were allocated to Hounslow, a garage with a capacity of 72. This was mainly achieved by parking buses on a plot of land behind the garage that was also used to stand vehicles terminating there on layover. The garage was rebuilt in the early 1950s and included a new bus station in front of the garage. The planned allocation was now up to 120 vehicles, although the allocation in 2002 was 127.

Hounslow's first one man operated double deckers were MCW Metrobuses delivered in 1982 for routes 111 and 202. With the allocation still high, Hounslow runs a number of night services on behalf of other London United garages to enable it to fit the buses into the garage. It was also the first garage in London to operate a low-floor bus with the arrival of Wright Pathfinder bodied Dennis Lance SLF in December 1993.[10]

There were plans to relocate the garage away from the town centre, and allow the expansion of the adjoining bus station. In 2005 an unsuccessful planning application for a site in Hanworth Road was lodged. This was largely due to a campaign by residents overlooking the site.

In late 2007 the bus station in front of the garage was closed for rebuilding. The overall roof was removed and the eight bus bays demolished. In their place have been built just two stands for routes 120 and route 281. The other seven routes that previously served the bus station now stand on the garage forecourt (the old bus station) but pick up passengers in the road outside. One exception was route 81, where buses ran out of service to and from the bus stand at Isleworth Fire Station however this has since been discontinued and buses again turn around in the bus station.

On 2 September 2006, London United commenced operating routes 203, 697 and 698.

On 3 May 2010, route 698 was transferred from this garage to Hounslow Heath (HH) garage.

On 4 October 2014, route 110 was transferred to this garage from Fulwell (FW) garage.

On 24 June 2017, route 120 passed to Metroline and route 419 was transferred from Shepherd's Bush (S) garage to this garage.

On 16 September 2017, route 222 passed to Metroline.

On 30 June 2018, route 419 was transferred from this garage to Fulwell (FW) garage. Routes 696, 697 and parts of routes H32 and H98 were transferred from this garage to Hounslow Heath (HH) garage at the same time.

On 26 January 2019, route N9 was transferred from this garage to Stamford Brook (V) garage.

On 18 March 2019, routes 696, 697 and the Hounslow Heath (HH) allocation for routes H32 and H98 were transferred from Hounslow Heath (HH) garage to this garage.

On 27 July 2019, route 81 passed to Metroline.

On 29 May 2021 London United commend operation on route E1.

On 12 June 2021, the allocation of route 419 was transferred to this garage. At the game time routes 116 and 423 was transferred to Hounslow Heath (HH) garage from the this garage.

On 4 September 2021, London United commended operation on route 117.

On 30 April 2022, route 111 past to Abellio London. At the same time route 105 (nights only) was transferred back from this garage to Hounslow Heath (WK) garage.

On 3 May 2022 route 635 was transferred to this garage from Hounslow Heath (WK) garage.

Bus types in use[]

Alexander Dennis Enviro 200 Dart 10.2m (DE) for routes 117 and 419

Alexander Dennis Enviro 400 10.2m (ADE) for route 635

Alexander Dennis Enviro 400H 10.2m (ADH) for route E1

Alexander Dennis Enviro 200 Dart 10.8m (DLE) for routes 117 and H22

Alexander Dennis E20D 10.9m / Enviro 200 MMC (DLE) for routes 110, 117 and H22

Alexander Dennis E20D 11.5m / Enviro 200 MMC (DXE) for routes 117 and H37

Mercedes-Benz O530 Citaro 12.0m (MCL) for route 117

Mercedes-Benz Citaro K 10.6m (MCM) for routes 117 and 203

Scania OmniCity 10.6m & 10.8m (SP) for routes 203, H32 and H98

New Routemaster 11.3m (LT) for route H32

Hounslow Heath (WK)[]

As of May 2022 Hounslow Heath garage operates London bus routes 105, 116, 216, 235, 411 and 423

History[]

Hounslow Heath was the original operating base of Stanwell Buses, a company set up by London Buses just prior to deregulation. They traded as Westlink, hence the garage code WK, and initially operated routes 116, 117 and 203 which were all joint Transport for London/Surrey County Council contracts. In 1999 Westlink was taken over by London United and recoded internally as HH. London Buses still use the code WK. The depot has also been extended over the former Travellers Coaches yard next door.

On 3 May 2010, route 698 was transferred to this garage from Hounslow (AV) garage.

On 2 October 2010, routes 411 and 641 passed to Quality Line.

On 12 January 2013, London United commenced operating route 635.

On 21 March 2015, route 482 passed to Metroline.

On 8 August 2015, the allocation for route 216 was transferred to this garage from Fulwell (FW) garage.

On 2 July 2016, route 216 was transferred to Fulwell (FW) garage from this garage, except certain trips worked off route 696 allocation.

On 9 December 2017, London United commenced operating route E10.

On 30 June 2018, London United RATP commenced operating route 105 and route H22 was transferred from this garage to Hounslow (AV) garage. Routes 696, 697 and part of routes H32 and H98 were transferred from Hounslow (AV) garage to this garage at the same time.

On 18 March 2019, the allocation for 696, 697 and 698 and parts of route H32 and route H98 were transferred back to Hounslow (AV).

On 1 June 2019, Route E10 passed to Abellio London

On 27 June 2020 route 285 passed to Abellio London.

On 8 May 2021 routes 216 and 411 was transferred to this garage.

On 29 May 2021 route 698 was transferred to London Sovereign. At the same time routes routes 635, 696 and 697 was transferred to this garage from Hounslow (AV) garage and route 105 nights only was transferred to Hounslow (AV) garage.

On 12 June 2021, routes 116 and 423 was transferred to this garage.

On 8 January 2022, London United commenced operation on route 235.

On 30 April 2022, route 105 (nights only) was transferred back to this garage from Hounslow (AV) garage.

On 3 May 2022, route 635 was transferred from this garage to Hounslow (AV) garage.

On 16 May 2022, routes 696 and 697 was transferred back to Hounslow (AV) garage from this garage.

Route 411 will be transfer to Tolworth (TV) garage from this garage from 3 December 2022.

Bus types in use[]

Alexander Dennis E20D 10.9m / Enviro 200 MMC (DLE) for routes 216, 235 and 411

Alexander Dennis Enviro 400 10.2m (ADE) for route 635

BYD D9UR 10.9m / Enviro 200 MMC EV (BE) for route 235

Volvo B5LH 10.6m / Wright Eclipse Gemini 3 (VH) for routes 105, 116 and 423

Park Royal (RP)[]

As of February 2021, Park Royal garage operates London bus routes 18, 223, 224, 266, 440 and 24-hour route 220 and night routes N18 and N266

History[]

Park Royal was opened by NCP Challenger on 26 May 2007, on the site of the former Metroline garage (HR) in Atlas Road, Harlesden, which had closed in 2005.

The garage is actually located in a 3 places boundary, which are Park Royal, North Acton and Old Oak Common.

On 11 November 2017, London United commenced operating routes 18 and N18. At the same time, routes 220, 283, 440 and E11 were transferred from Park Royal (PK) garage to this garage.

On 6 January 2018, routes 398 and H17 were transferred from London Sovereign's Harrow (SO) garage to this garage.

On 13 October 2018, London United commenced operating routes 223 and 224.

On 25 May 2019, route E11 passed to Abellio London.

On 7 December 2019, London United commenced operating routes 266 and N266.

On 27th February 2021 route 283 was transferred from this garage to Shepherd’s Bush (S) garage.

Bus types in use

Alexander Dennis Enviro 400 10.2m (ADE) for routes 220, 266 and N266

Alexander Dennis Enviro 400H 10.2m (ADH) for routes 266 and N266

Alexander Dennis E20D 10.5m / Enviro 200 MMC (DME) for route 440

Alexander Dennis E20D 10.9m / Enviro 200 MMC (DLE) for routes 223, and 224

Volvo B5LH 10.6m / Wright Eclipse Gemini 3 (VH) for routes 18 and N18

Wright StreetDeck 10.6m (WH) for routes 18 and N18

Shepherd's Bush (S)[]

As of September 2021, Shepherd's Bush garage operates London bus routes 49, 70, 72, 283, C1 and 24-hour routes 94 and 148 and night route N72.

History[]

Shepherd's Bush garage opened in 1906.

On 20 October 2012, routes 272 and C1 were transferred to this garage from Park Royal (PK) garage.

On 31 May 2014, route 419 was transferred to this garage from Stamford Brook (V) garage.

On 6 September 2014, route 49 passed to Abellio London.

On 25 October 2014, the Park Royal allocation of route 72 was transferred to this garage.

On 5 March 2016, route N97 passed to Tower Transit.

On 24 June 2017, London United commenced operating route 70 and route 272 was transferred from this garage to Stamford Brook (V) garage. Route 419 was transferred from this garage to Hounslow (AV) garage at the same time.

On 21 October 2017, the night service for route 220 was transferred from this garage to Park Royal (PK) garage.

On 18 May 2019, London United commenced operating route N72. Part the allocation of route 265 was transferred to this garage at the same time.

On 28 September 2019, the allocation for route 265 from this garage was withdrawn due to the short workings being withdrawn.

On 27th February 2021 route 283 was transferred to this garage from Park Royal (RP) garage.

On 4 September 2021, London United commended operation on route 49.

Bus types in use[]

Alexander Dennis Enviro 200 Dart 10.2m (DE) for routes 72 and N72

BYD D9UR 10.9m / Enviro 200 EV (BE) for routes 70 and C1

Alexander Dennis E20D 10.9m / Enviro 200 MMC (DLE) for route 283

Alexander Dennis Enviro 400H 10.2m (ADH) for route 49

BYD DD Electric 10.9m / Enviro 400 EV City (BCE) for routes 49, 94 and 148

New Routemaster 11.3m (LT) for route 49, 148

Stamford Brook (V)[]

As of December 2019, Stamford Brook garage operates London bus routes 9, 211, 272, 306, 391, E3 and night routes N9

History[]

Stamford Brook opened as a bus garage in 1980 after a two year construction. Originally built as Chiswick Tram depot, it had latterly been used to operate the British Airways bus service between Heathrow Airport and the West London Air Terminal in Kensington.

The original plan was to create a temporary home for the Riverside garage buses and staff whilst that garage was re-built with a view to taking on the workload from Mortlake and Turnham Green which were to close. However this idea was changed and the garage took on the work from Turnham Green which closed and also inherited the garage code V. Following service reductions, Mortlake and Riverside closed in 1983, with some of their work moving to Stamford Brook.

In 1981 Stamford Brook took on Airbus routes A1 and A2 following the withdrawal of the existing British Airways services between Heathrow Airport and central London. These vehicles were transferred in 1994 to West Ramp (which became an outstation of V) leaving the garage with an allocation of MCW Metroriders, MCW Metrobuses, Leyland Olympians and Dennis Darts.

The garage closed in 1996 and became a store for unlicensed buses held for possible future use. In 1999 it reopened to cater for increased demand in the area. In 2001 the allocation consisted entirely of Dennis Darts. When route 9 was converted from AEC Routemaster to one man operation in September 2004, it moved from Shepherds Bush, and East Lancs Myllennium Vyking bodied Volvo B7TL double deckers appeared.

On 27 November 2005, London United commenced operating route 27.

On 30 January 2010, London United commenced operating route 10.

On 2 March 2013, route 419 was transferred to this garage from Twickenham (NC) garage.

On 31 May 2014, route 419 was transferred to Shepherds Bush (S) garage.

On 31 May 2014, London United commenced operating route E3.

On 31 May 2014, the night service of route 27 was transferred to this garage from Hounslow (AV) garage.

On 24 June 2017, route 272 was transferred from Shepherd's Bush (S) garage to this garage.

On 24 November 2018, route 10 was withdrawn and route 391 was transferred from Fulwell (FW) garage to this garage.

On 26 January 2019, route N9 was transferred to this garage from Hounslow (AV) garage.

On 9 March 2019, London United commenced operating route N27.

On 29 June 2019, London United commenced operating route 211.

On 9 November 2019, routes 27 and N27 passed to Abellio London.

On 7 December 2019, London United commenced operating route 306

Bus types in use[]

Alexander Dennis Enviro 200 Dart 10.8m (DLE) for route 391

Alexander Dennis Enviro 400H 10.1m & 10.2m (ADH) for route E3

Alexander Dennis E20D 10.5m / Enviro 200 MMC (DME) for route 272

Volvo B5LH 10.6m / Wright Eclipse Gemini 3 (VH) for route 306

New Routemaster 11.3m (LT) for routes 9, 211 and N9

Tolworth (TV)[]

As of August 2023, Tolworth garage operates London bus routes 293, 406, 411, 412, 418, 465, 467, K1, K2, K4, K5 and S3 and school bus routes 613, 627, 655, 662, 665 and 685

History[]

Tolworth is one of the newest London bus garages and was built on the site of a former coal yard behind Tolworth railway station.

Tolworth was originally planned in the late 1990s following the closure of Kingston Garage and the announcement that the site was to be part sold off and part converted into the new bus station. A recruitment centre was opened on Tolworth Broadway long before building work ever started.

The sale of the Kingston site was brought forward somewhat, and this appeared to catch out the operator as Tolworth Garage was not yet ready. Buses were temporarily parked in a car park in Kingston until the new 100 capacity bus garage opened in early 2002.

On 30 June 2007, routes 406 and 418 passed to Quality Line.

On 2 July 2011, route K5 passed to Quality Line.

On 3 September 2011, route 467 passed to Quality Line.

On 29 June 2013, routes K1 and K3 passed to Abellio London.

On 31 May 2014, route 131 was transferred to this garage from Fulwell (FW) garage.

On 2 July 2016, route 57 passed to London General.

On 2 July 2016, routes 71 (except certain trips worked off route 65 night allocation) and 671 was transferred to this garage from Fulwell (FW) garage.

On 2 July 2016, London United recommenced operating route 85.

On 7 August 2017, part of route 131's allocation was transferred to Fulwell (FW) garage.

On 29 August 2017, the Fulwell (FW) allocation for route 131 was transferred from Fulwell (FW) garage to this garage.

On 30 September 2017, route 131 passed to London General.

On 13 October 2018, route 965 was discontinued

On 25 April 2020 London United took over routes 406, 418 and 465

On 29 August 2020 London United took over route 467

On 8 May 2021, route 463 passed to Metrobus.

On 12 June 2021, routes 85, 406 School extra only and 418 school extra only was transferred to Fulwell (FW) garage from this garage.

On 19 June 2021, the operation on routes 293, 404, 467 and 470 were transferred from Quality Line to this garage.

On 4 December 2021, London United commenced operating route 655.

On 1 July 2023, Route 265 passed to London General.

On 19 August 2023, London United commenced operation on route 685.

On 30 September 2023, routes 404 and 466 passed to Abellio London

Bus types in use[]

Alexander Dennis Enviro 200 Dart 8.9m (SDE) for routes 404, K5 and S3

Alexander Dennis E20D 9.0m / Enviro 200 MMC (SDE) for routes 404, K1, K4 and S3

Alexander Dennis E20D 10.5m / Enviro 200 MMC (DXE) for route 293

Alexander Dennis E20D 10.9m / Enviro 200 MMC (DLE) for routes 293, 411, 465 and K2

Volvo B5LH 10.6m / Wright Eclipse Gemini 3 (VH) for routes 293, 406, 418, 613, 627, 662 and 685

Alexander Dennis Enviro 400 Trident 10.2m (ADE) for routes 293, 411, 412, 467, 613, 655 and 662

Kingston Christmas Park & Ride K50[]

London United operate route K50, the Kingston to Chessington World of Adventures, Christmas Park & Ride service. The service runs daily from early November to mid-January each year.[11]

‘’’Wandsworth (JE)’’’[]

‘’’History’’’[]

London United will commence operating 28 and N28 from 1 May 2021.

London United Will commenced operating 639 and 670 from 5 June 2021.

‘’’Bus Type in use’’’[]

Volvo B5LH 10.4m / Wright Eclipse Gemini 2 (VH) to be introduced to routes 28 and N28 from 1 May 2021 and 639 and 670 from 5 June 2021

Former Garages[]

Park Royal (PK)[]

History[]

On 13 November 2009, London United took over the operations of this garage.

On 3 July 2010, London United commenced operating route C1.

On 20 October 2012, the daytime service for route 220 was transferred to this garage from Shepherds Bush (S) garage. Routes 272 and C1 were transferred from this garage to Shepherd's Bush (S) garage at the same time.

On 21 October 2017, the night service for route 220 was transferred from Shepherd's Bush (S) garage to this garage.

On 11 November 2017, Park Royal (PK) garage was announced closed and routes 220, 283, 440, E11 were transferred from this garage to Park Royal (RP) garage.

Twickenham (NC)[]

History[]

On 12 November 2005, Twickenham garage was opened by NCP Challenger.

On 31 March 2012, 493 passed to London General.

On 1 March 2013, Twickenham was announced closed and route 33 was transferred to Fulwell (FW) and route 419 to Stamford Brook (V).

Twickenham (NC) currently has no London routes at present and is used for United Motorcoaches
